reviewText: Being a movie buff, I was surprised I had never seen this movie or heard much of it when it was shown on a bus from Massachusetts to New York. Since I knew nothing about it, I had very low expectations (my guess is it didn't  do too well at the box office), and was surprised to see the wonderful  Shirley MacLaine and the consistently good Brendan Fraser. On the other  hand, I did not recognize Ricki Lake at all, even though I have seen some  J. Waters movie she was in. I had to wait until the credits to find out who  it was. Brendan Fraser has turned out to be one of the best actors of his  generation, if not for his choice of movies. Hopefully Gods and Monsters  will open some doors for more serious roles. However, he shows a very good  comedic timing in Mrs. Winterbourne, and did very well against Ms.  MacLaine. Overall this is a very funny and entertaining movie.

reviewText: Though a box office dissapointment, this romantic comedy is unexpectedly a very enjoyable one. It's not perfect. It owes too much to While You Were Sleeping and the timing of the film is a bit off kilter but it succeeds  none-the-less. Shirley Maclaine is, as always, absolutely wonderful.  Brendan Fraser is good also (though his character's transition is somewhat  flimsy) and Ricki Lake does fine in the role of Connie even if her  performance is a bit rough around the edges. What sets this romantic comedy  apart from all the others is the fact that it takes a surpising turn that  involves a murder and this lends the film alot more interest. I think that  if critics had not panned this movie so badly it had the potential to be a  big hit. It's definatly worth watching.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, this movie is cute if not completely unrealistic, improbable and beyond predictable.  I liked it, but I have to be realistic when I say that this is not a great movie.  The acting is subpar (MacLaine really should have been in more of the film) and the script is very generic.  There are all your usual plot twists and developments, the characters are very unoriginal and the ending is as far fetched as they come.The story is that of Connie Doyle, a young woman who leaves home at a young age, winds up living with a creep named Steve who gets her pregnant and throws her out.  When she meets Hugh Winterbourne and his lovely new wife Patricia she makes quick friends, but when the train they are on crashes and Hugh and Patricia are killed Connie finds herself being mistaken by Hugh's family (who had never met Patricia) for Hugh's wife, and the baby she is carrying is mistaken as Hugh's baby.  She tries to explain, but the Winterbourne's generosity is more than she has ever experienced, and since she has no where to go she decides to let them believe what they want to believe.  Hugh's twin brother Bill is skeptical but soon he falls in love with Connie and this makes her decision all the more difficult to make.Ricki Lake is not a good actress.  There, I said it.  She manages to make Connie very unbelievable and comes off very scripted here.  Brendan Fraser is also a very tasteless actor.  I adored him in `Gods & Monsters' but that was like a one time thing for him.  His performance here is not awful, but it is not charming or even becoming.  Loren Dean is despicable as Steve, and so I guess he is serviceable (although I loathe characters like his, so much so that it makes it difficult for me to enjoy the film).  Shirley MacLaine is always amazing, even when the movie is not.  As Grace she is delightful, funny and very watchable.  I only wish she was in more of the film.There are moments to enjoy here, and the film overall is decent, just nothing new or anything to really get excited over.  I can see how, if this is a film that you grew up on or enjoyed as a child you may have a special place for it in your heart, but for a fan of the genre in general there are plenty of better places to look than this one.The fact remains that `Mrs. Winterbourne' is nothing new, and it doesn't have the great performances to bolster its lack of originality and warrant our attention.  MacLaine cannot carry this film on her own, and Lake and Fraser do nothing special to make this a film worthy of our time.  Watch a Jennifer Lopez film (that JLo if you're down) instead.
summary: It's cute, but overall it's a miss...

reviewText: Amen, sister, we hear ya!  So Rikki Lake isn't a great actress.  At least she manages to be funny and likable in this little romantic comedy that's in no way realistic but a cute fairy tale that lots of people wish would happen to them.  Lake plays Connie Doyle, a down and out young girl who leaves home because she doesn't get along with her father and takes up with a no-good womanizing criminal named Steve DeCunzo (Loren Dean).  She is thrown out into the street after the scumbag refuses to accept responsibility for her pregnancy and, through an odd turn of events meets a wealthy young couple, Hugh Winterbourne and wife Patricia on a train that's headed for Boston.  Both the women are pregnant and, after trying on Patricia's ring and clothes, there is a horrible trainwreck in which Connie is the only one of the three to survive.  Mistaking her and the baby to be Hugh Winterborne's wife and child, she is welcomed openly by the matriarch, played by a feisty, eccentric Shirley McClain and met with suspicion by Hugh's twin brother Bill, dual roles played by Brendan Fraser, who is by far the best thing about this movie.Naturally, as in all fairy tales, Connie wins Bill over and he proposes marriage to her.  Okay, so he moved a bit fast just after his brother's death, and we all know that women like Connie Doyle--or Rikki Lake for that matter--are not the type of woman a handsome, wealthy guy is going to fall for.  Suspend your disbelief merely on the premise of fun.  Just when everything seems to be turning out well for our underdog, who shows up with blackmail on his mind but Steve, and now he has an interest in his baby after all.  Money talks...Complete with a humorously awkward priest, a crazy Cuban Butler, and other lively characters that compensate for Lake's not-so-stellar performance, this movie manages to be a likable comic escape and fun to watch every now and then.  Not meant to be earthshakingly fabulous due to its lack of originality, at least it's appealing on the premise of wishful thinking and makes you wish dreams came true that easily.  Oh, wouldn't it be nice if life was really like that?
summary: "You Be Careful, Cookie.  Those Things Can Do a Lot of Damage."

reviewText: We first rented this video, and overall loved the storyline. It was predictable as all Romantic comedies are, and a little sappy and unbelievable as all romance novels are. However it was still enjoyable. As a fan of Brendan Fraser, I have to say that as always, he's adorable in this movie. At first you hate is character, but by the end you love him. And despite the foul language coming from Ricky Lake's character, you fall in love with the fact that Brendan's character is still cute. I think the real reason that they inserted the bad language coming from her, was to stress the major class differences in each of them in the story. Thus said I do not agree with the bad language (this factor in the story makes it impossible to be a family movie)-but I do understand why they thought that they needed to put it in. The beginning is a little slow, and not that great, but the ending is classic, and perfectly adorable. I rate it a four and not a five  simply due to the language. If not for that, it would have been a five with me. If you are considering, and have never seen this, rent it first, and screen it without the kids in the room. Cute overall storyline.
summary: if your into Romance Novels, and Sappy Romantic Comedies, you will love this!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great update of an old, rather dark version of the same story that starred Barbara Stanwyck.  I liked this one much better, because it's funny and serious at the same time.  Connie, who has gotten pregnant and is really down on her luck, meets a nice guy, Hugh, and his wife, Patricia, on a train.  Patricia is also pregnant, and when the train wrecks and they are killed, Connie is mistaken for the wife.  The family takes her in and, of course, she begins to feel guilty about deceiving them as she comes to love and respect them all.  The plot becomes more and more tangled, until it finally unravels to a happy ending.  A nice rainy day, cup of cocoa watch.

reviewText: I've seen other movies that are better polished in their presentation and where the leads have better chemistry (though the leads are just fine and likable otherwise), yet this movie still has a genuinely warm heart at its center, especially for women, from what I've noticed.  There's also something to be said about the fact that this happened to be one of my late Mom's favorite movies, not to mention the favorite of the owner's wife at a local video store, who undoubtedly saw more than her share of great movies.  Who hasn't dreamed of a better life and of finally finding that elusive happiness?  And that's exactly what Mrs. Winterbourne does:  It fulfills your dreams, if only for 2 hours.
summary: This movie speaks to people who have unfulfilled dreams, and who doesn't?

reviewText: Just years before LEGALLY BLONDE and MISS CONGENIALITY came the delightful  feel-good "Cinderella" rom-com MRS. WINTERBOURNE directed by Actor/comedian Dick Benjamin.The film starts with a murdered corpse in a motel room and a confession of murder.Where is this all going?Connie Doyle (Ricki Lake) has been knocked up and kicked to he curb by the heartless scumbag,Steve (a truly creepy Loren Dean).Pregnant and homeless,Connie serendipitously boards a train bound for Boston where she meets Hugh Winterbourne Brendan Fraser in a double role) and his also pregnant wife,Patricia.As Connie is trying on Patricia's wedding band, the train wrecks.Next thing we know,Connie awakes in the hospital,having given birth to a baby boy,and she is mistaken for the now-widowed Patricia setting off a series of twists of fate that will bring into the wealthy Winterbourne family,headed by the saucy,pill-popping,booze-hound,Mother Winterbourne (an always perfect Shirley MacLaine) and Hugh's remaining identical twin brother,Bill (who else but Brendan Fraser).A world of madcap hilarity and heartwarming touches ensue as Connie,now Patricia Winterbourne and the family come to terms with each other. Throw in the gay houseman,Paco (always funny Miguel Sandoval) and another exquisite continuous sprightly soundtrack by my favorite, Patrick Doyle, and you have 106 minutes of charming,left-of-center comedy.It is formulaic in a sense, but heartfelt excellent performances makes MRS.WINTERBOURNE all the more delightful.Like A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM, all of the foibles of humanity are exposed and all turns out right,just like it should.After all, that is what we want anyway.5 stars for the undeniably "cute" factor.
summary: Murder and serendipity in the Winterbourne family

reviewText: Ricki Lake plays a homeless/destitute mother-to-be who is befriended by a family of wealth and importance once they believe her to be the widow of one of theirs who has perished in a train wreck. Brendan Fraser and Shirley Maclaine dominate as her "new family", with Brendan this time out playing the stronger-family-member comic role to perfection and Shirley this time out playing the anxious/comic mother responding with an outsized emotional reaction to every little thing her uptight son does. Fraser and Maclaine play a classic 1930's Hollywood comic duo to perfection and keep the film rolling at a sprightly pace until its unexpected ending. All in all an absolute delight even if Ricki Lake, a charismatic television personality in her own right, does not have the spectacular "superstar" comic flair of Fraser and Maclaine at their best. This is a filming of a novel entitled "I Married A Dead Man".

reviewText: I watch this movie periodically just to see how tremendously talented (and still, sadly, UNDERused by Hollywood) Brendan Fraser is.Basic Story with SPOILERS (remake of old B&W; drama, was a novel first, liberally changed in this comedic reinterpretation): Pregnant Protagonist meets pregnant lady and cute hubby on train. Train crashes. Preg. Protagonist is believed to be dead married lady (cause she had tried on wedding ring of lady), whose hubby happens to come from family with beaucoup bucks. She tries to play the part of "Mrs. Winterbourne", falls for brother of dead guy (the twin). Confusion and comedic events ensue. Happy ending. Wedding. Hurrah!So, now, my take on the weaknesses and strengths:Here you have a pretty mediocre script, an okay director, and, except for Rikki Lake, a really good lead cast. Rikki sucks. She sucks so bad that I wanted to take the original celluloid and edit it myself so she wasn't in any of the scenes, then edit in someone else. Someone who could, well, you see, maybe, ACT.If they had simply paired with Brendan someone with real acting chops and comedic timing, this would get 4 stars from me and would qualify as a decent little comedy. It gets one star for Shirley and two for Brendan. He manages to be romantic, funny and a bit sad, and boy, is he totally to die for in the tango scene. Women, prepare to swoon. He's adorably funny and touching in the "making a list of pros and con" scene.The biggest flaw in this film, hands down, is Rikki Lake. She simply has no onscreen charisma, negligible acting talent, and no comedic timing whatsoever. She can't hold up her end, so the movie doesn't rise. And she's totally painful to watch in some scenes. I mean, CRINGE painful. (That is not figurative. I actually cringed.) What a shame. Brendan is so good, he deserved a better partner. When Miss Lake was heavy, she got cast as a novelty actress. But I've seen her in Hairdo and in this flick, and she simply cannot act. Period. Stick to talk shows, Rikki.The movie has a "tv film" feel to it. If it weren't for Shirley and Brendan, you'd think you were watching a movie of the week. Well, I still recommend you watch it for the amazing Mr. Fraser. Hollywood needs to put this man in more funny or dramatic films. He's just got "it".Mir
summary: Brendan Fraser and Shirley McL rock. Rikki Lake stinks.
